statement.tex: \text{Find the distance between the point P $(7,2,4)$}\\ \text{and the plane determined by the points,} \\ A(2, 5, -3), B(-2, -3. 5)\text{ and }C(5, 3, -3).

step.reason: \text{If $\ora{r}$ is the position vector to any point on} \\ \text{the plane, and $\ora{A}$, $\ora{B}$ and $\ora{C}$ are three points} \\ \text{on the plane, then,}\\ \begin{array}{|c|c|} \hline \textbf{Vector} & \textbf{Orientation} \\ \hline \ora{r}-\ora{A} & \text{along the plane} \\ \ora{B}-\ora{A} & \text{along the plane} \\ \ora{C}-\ora{A} & \text{along the plane} \\ \hline (\ora{B}-\ora{A})\times(\ora{C}-\ora{A}) & \text{normal to the plane} \\ \hline \end{array} \\ \therefore\text{ for any point $\ora{r}$ on the plane} \\ (\ora{r}-\ora{A})\cdot[(\ora{B}-\ora{A}) \times(\ora{C}-\ora{A})]=0

step.context: \text{If }(\ora{r}-\ora{A})\cdot [(\ora{B}-\ora{A})\times(\ora{C}-\ora{A})]=0 \\ \text{and A, B and C are }(2, 5, -3), (-2, -3. 5)\text{ and } \\ (5, 3, -3)\text{ respectively. is this is the vector} \\ \text{notation for equation of the plane?}

\text{If \ora{P} is point on a plane{\bf parallel} to the plane} \\ \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{2}{3}{4})=7, \\ \text{and $\ora{r}$ is a point on this plane containing P,} \\ \text{then is the following true?}
step.reason: \text{Since the plane containing P is parallel to} \\ \text{the plane } \\ \begin{array}{c} \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{2}{3}{4})=7, \end{array} \\ \text{any vector along the plane containing P would} \\ \text{be $\perp$ to the common normal of the two planes.} \\ \text{Hence, } \\ \begin{array}{c} (\ora{r}-\ora{P})\cdot\dfrac{(\vector{2}{3}{4})}{\sqrt{29}}=0 \end{array}

step.context: \text{If this is the plane containing A, B and C} \\ \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{2}{3}{4})=7, \\ \text{and this is a parallel plane containing P} \\ \ora{r}\cdot(\vector{2}{3}{4})=36, \\ \text{then what is the separation between P and the} \\ \text{the plane containing A, B and C?}
